title: 110_hr3133
content: The Act may be cited as the "Financial Literacy for Homeowners Act". The Congress acknowledges that expanded access to credit has led to high homeownership rates but is concerned about predatory lending practices that make it costly for low-income families. Borrowers with fair to good credit can access loans in the prime mortgage market with the lowest rates and costs. Borrowers with fair to good credit ratings can get loans in the prime mortgage market with low interest rates. Those with blemished credit histories turn to the subprime market, facing higher rates and fees. Some subprime lenders engage in predatory lending with unjustifiably high rates and fees. Predatory loans, often targeting minority neighborhoods, come with high interest rates, excessive fees, and unfair terms, stripping away wealth accumulated over a lifetime. Some communities lacking access to traditional institutions fall victim to second mortgage lenders and finance companies offering high-interest home equity loans with steep fees. Predatory lending practices targeted cash-poor homeowners with high-interest home equity loans and excessive fees, leading to struggles with mortgage payments and foreclosure. A joint report by HUD and the Treasury aimed to address this issue. The joint report by HUD and the Department of the Treasury in 2000 called for legislation to curb predatory home mortgage lending by restricting abusive terms, improving consumer literacy, and prohibiting harmful sales practices. It also proposed a four-point plan to address predatory lending practices. The joint report in 2000 proposed a four-point plan to address predatory lending practices, including improving consumer literacy, requiring lenders to recommend home mortgage counseling, disclosing credit scores to borrowers, and providing timely and accurate loan information. Predatory lending is a major issue that needs to be addressed to protect borrowers from high-pressure sales tactics and misleading information about interest rates. More efforts are needed to help borrowers with predatory loans, educate consumers about the risks of home loans, and guide them to appropriate resources. To educate consumers about the dangers of home loans and refer them to appropriate resources for assistance. SEC. 3. GRANT PROGRAM FOR EDUCATION AND COUNSELING REGARDING PREDATORY LENDING. The Secretary of the Treasury may provide grants to States, local governments, and nonprofits for eligible anti-predatory lending activities, including education programs to inform vulnerable consumers about predatory lending practices related to home loans. The curr_chunk discusses predatory lending practices targeting vulnerable groups in home loans, such as low-income borrowers and senior citizens, with high interest rates, excessive fees, and fraudulent terms. Counseling programs by certified organizations aim to educate homeowners about these practices. The curr_chunk provides homeownership counseling and referral services for homeowners and prospective homeowners regarding predatory lending practices in home loans. The curr_chunk outlines the eligibility and application process for grants related to investigating predatory lending practices in home loans. Applicants must submit a detailed application to the Secretary for consideration. The Secretary will consider grant applications from States, local governments, and nonprofits for activities eligible under subsection (b). The maximum grant amount for any single grantee in a fiscal year is $1,000,000. Selection criteria will be established by the Secretary to choose recipients for the grants. SEC. 4. TOLL-FREE TELEPHONE NUMBER FOR PREDATORY LENDING COMPLAINTS. The Secretary will establish a toll-free telephone number for consumer complaints about predatory lending practices related to home loans. The number will provide information, refer borrowers with predatory loans to appropriate agencies, and coordinate with State and nonprofit organizations to create a consumer resource database. The toll-free telephone line will receive consumer complaints and provide information through a live person, not recordings. SEC. 5. PREDATORY LENDING ADVISORY COUNCIL. Established in the Department of the Treasury, the Predatory Lending Advisory Council advises the Secretary on issues related to predatory lending practices for home loans. The Council consists of 13 members appointed by the Secretary, including representatives from community-based organizations working to improve distressed neighborhoods and assist borrowers with predatory loans. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council, established in the Department of the Treasury, advises on predatory lending practices for home loans. It includes members from community-based organizations, state agencies, private homeowners familiar with mortgages, and representatives from the private real estate sector. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council, under the Department of the Treasury, consists of members from community-based organizations, state agencies, private homeowners, and representatives from the real estate industry. Members serve two-year terms, with initial appointments split between one and two years. They receive travel expenses but no compensation. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council members serve without compensation but receive travel expenses. The Secretary designates a chairperson, and the Council must meet at least three times a year, with the authority to hold public hearings when necessary. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council has the authority to hold public hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. It provides advice to the Secretary on the grant program, toll-free telephone number, and coordination of activities related to preventing predatory lending practices. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council conducts a study on the root causes of default and foreclosure of home loans, using empirical data. A report is to be submitted to the Secretary and Congress within 12 months of the Council's full membership appointment. The Predatory Lending Advisory Council will submit a report to the Secretary and Congress within 12 months of its full membership appointment, detailing recommendations for consumer protection legislation on predatory lending practices in home loans. SEC. 6. DEFINITIONS. The term "home loan" under this Act refers to a loan secured by residential property, including home equity lines of credit and home improvement loans. The term "nonprofit organization" in this Act is defined as per the Cranston-Gonzalez National Affordable Housing Act, excluding a specific subparagraph. "Predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" encompasses making loans solely based on the borrower's home. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes making loans solely based on the borrower's home equity without considering the borrower's ability to repay, leading to unaffordable terms for the borrower. The term "predatory or unscrupulous lending practice" includes inadequate disclosures of loan terms, inducing repeated refinancing with additional fees, and engaging in fraud to deceive borrowers. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Treasury, and "State" includes various regions like Puerto Rico and Guam. "Unit of general local government" pertains to cities or towns. The term "unit of general local government" refers to cities, towns, townships, parishes, villages, or other political subdivisions of a State. Authorization of Appropriations: $55,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2008-2012. $2,000,000 for section 4 and $5,000,000 for section 5. Secretary may issue necessary regulations.
